questions.Question: Which Fundamental Right in the Indian Constitution states that all persons shall be equally protected by the laws of the country?
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to Equality emphasize that all persons are equal before law irrespective of their economic or social status. However, this right is not absolute and are subject to some restrictions. President Governors Diplomats cannot be prosecuted during the time of hold in office.

questions.Question: Which Fundamental Right in the Indian Constitution includes equal access to shops bathing ghats hotels etc?
questions.optionA: Right to Liberty and Personal Freedom
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to equality ensures everyone equal access to shops, bathing ghats, hotels etc, irrespective to caste, religion, creed, sex etc. The article ensures social and economic equality.

questions.Question: Which Fundamental Right in the Indian CoilStitution includes abolition of untouchability?
questions.optionA: Right to Liberty and Personal Freedom
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to equality under Article-17 of the constitution prohibited untouchability. However constitution itself does not prescribe any punishment but Parliament has the freedom to legislate to make provision more stringent.

questions.Question: When was the 'Right to Information' enacted in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to Information Act was enacted 15th June 2005 and came into force on 12th October 2005. It aims at providing access to citizens of information under government control thereby promoting transparency and accountability. This act extends to whole of India except Jammu and Kashmir.

questions.Question: According to Indian constitution which is not a fundamental right-
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to information is not a fundamental right rather it is a legal right provided through Right to Information Act 2005. Right to education Right to Expression and Right to life are fundamental rights under Articles-21(A), 19 and 21 respectively.

questions.Question: What is the maximum number of members in Lok Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions under Article-81, Lok Sabha can have maximum of 552 members. Out of 552, 530 shall be elected from constituencies of States and 20 shall represent constituencies of Union Territories. Remaining 2 members can be nominated by President of India from Anglo-Indian community. Presently, there is strength of 545 in LokSabha. Out of which, 530 are from States, 13 from Union Territories and belongingAnglo-Indian community.

questions.Question: In Lok Sabha the total number of members from States are-
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions under Article-81, Lok Sabha can have maximum of 552 members. Out of 552, 530 shall be elected from constituencies of States and 20 shall represent constituencies of Union Territories. Remaining 2 members can be nominated by President of India from Anglo-Indian community. Presently, there is strength of 545 in LokSabha. Out of which, 530 are from States, 13 from Union Territories and belongingAnglo-Indian community.

questions.Question: If the Speaker, of Lok Sabha wants to resign,  whom does he resign-
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions under Article-94(b), Speaker of Lok Sabha may at any time, by writing a letter addressing to Deputy Speaker, can resign from his/her office. Similarly, Deputy Speaker can also resign by writing a letter addressing to the the Speaker of Lok Sabha.

questions.Question: A Member of Parliament will be suspended from his membership, if he absents the house continuously for-
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions under Articlel-101(4), if a member of either house of Parliament without permission of the house, remains absent from all meetings for a period of sixty days, he/she can be suspended from the house or house may declare his seat vacant.

questions.Question: The function of Protem Speaker is to-
questions.optionA:
Conduct the Proceedings of the House in the
absence of the Speaker
questions.optionB:
Officiate as Speaker when a Speaker is
unlikely to be elected
questions.optionC:
Swearing in members and hold charge till a
regular Speaker is elected
questions.optionD:
Check if the election certificates of members
are in order
questions.solution: Solution:		As soon as the new Lok Sabha is constituted, the President of India from among the newly elected members, appoints the seniormost (seniority in terms of membership of Parliament) member as the Protem Speaker. His functions include administering oath to the Lok Sabha members and presiding over the election of a new Speaker. With the election of Speaker, Protem Speaker ceases to be the presiding officer.

questions.Question: The ordinance by Governor will be valid in case of non-approval in State Legislature for a period of-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-213 confers power to Governor to promulgate ordinances anytime except when Legislative Assembly or where there is Legislative Council, both the houses, are in session. Ordinance issued by Governor is subject to approval of state legislature and it must be approved by state legislature within 6 weeks of its reassembly, otherwise it will cease to operate.

questions.Question: How many member of Anglo-Indian Community can be nominated by Governor in State Assembly-
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions of Article-333, Governor of a state can nominate one member belonging to Anglo Indian Community in state legislative assembly, if he is of the opinion that they are not adequately represented.

questions.Question: Who works as the chairman of State Planning Board-
questions.solution: Solution:		Chief Minister works as the chairman of State Planning Board. It is an advisory body which assists state government in formulating a development plan based on a scientific assessment of the resources available to state.

questions.Question: The constitution does not have the provision to impeach-
questions.optionB: Chief Justice of Any High Court
questions.solution: Solution:		Constitution of India defines provision to impeach President, Chief Justice of Supreme Court and Chief Justice of High Court under Articles-61, 124(4) and 217 respectively. But it does not have provision to impeach Governor, rather under Articlel-156, it says that Governor hold the office till the pleasure of President which means he can be removed any time by the President.

questions.Question: In which of the following matters, Governor can make recommendations to President- 1.Dismissal of Council of Ministers 2.Suspension of Judges of High Court 3.Dissolution of State Assembly 4.Declaration of failure of Constitutional Machinery in State
questions.solution: Solution:		Every fortnight Governor has to send a report to the President regarding affairs of administration in the state. This repot can be even a ground for imposition of president's rule in the state under Article-356, if it consists of declaration of failure of constitutional Machinery in state. In this case he can also recommend President to dismiss Council of Ministers or dissolve state assembly.

questions.Question: The Philosophy and values of the makers of constitution are reflected in-
questions.solution: Solution:		Philosophy and values of makers of constitution are reflected in preamble. It embodies the essence of entire constitution and sets out main objectives, which constituent assembly intended to achieve.

questions.Question: What is Popular Sovereignty-
questions.solution: Solution:		Popular Sovereignty is the principle, according to which the government is created by the consent of its people, through their elected representatives, who are source of all political powers.

questions.Question: "Population control and family planning" is listed in the list given in the________Seventh Schedule in the Constitution of India.
questions.solution: Solution:		Population control and family planning is listed in concurrent list in Seventh Schedule of the Constitution. Other items include Marriage, Divorce, Bankruptcy and Insolvency, Forests, Education, Trade Union etc.

questions.Question: Which of the following forms are/is described for India in the preamble of constitution-
questions.optionC:
A Sovereign, Socialist, Secular Democratic
Republic
questions.solution: Solution:		Preamble describes the nature of Indian state, It gives a clear picture about the type of India which is to be constituted i.e . a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic.

questions.Question: Which of the following is described as the 'Soul of the constitution'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Preamble is called the 'Soul of constitution' because whenever there arises any doubt in interpretation of constitution, matter is decided in light of preamble.

questions.Question: The Preventive Detention Act curtailed-
questions.solution: Solution:		Preventive detention infringes the right to freedom of the person who has been detained under preventive detention Act. Article-22 provides for protection against arrest and detention in certain cases, including preventive detention cases.

questions.Question: ______ writ is issued by a higher court (High Court or Supreme Court) when a lower court has considered a case going beyond its jurisdiction.
questions.solution: Solution:		Prohibition writ is issued by a higher court to lower court when latter has overstepped its jurisdiction. Other writs are Habeas Corpus Mandamus Quo-Warranto and Certiorari.

questions.Question: Under which of the following writs, a person is restricted to perform any duties for which he does not have the authority?
questions.solution: Solution:		Quo warranto writ is issued to ensure that person holding a public office is qualified to hold the office. It can be issued to restrict a person to perform duties or take action for which he does not have authority.

questions.Question: Under which one of the following writs anofficial can be prevented from taking an action which he is offlcially not entitled?
questions.solution: Solution:		Quo warranto writ is issued to ensure that person holding a public office is qualified to hold the office. It can be issued to restrict a person to perform duties or take action for which he does not have authority.

questions.Question: In the Constitution of India the 'Right to Constitutional Remedies' has been provided in Article-
questions.solution: Solution:		Remedies for enforcement of fundamental rights conferred by Part-III has been provided under Article-32 of constitution. This article provides the right to citizens to move directly to Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamntal rights and it gives Supreme Court, powers to issu writ to enforce fundamental rights of an individual.

questions.Question: Who is the father of 'Utilitarian School of Thought'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill are known as the Father of 'Utilitarian School of Thought'. Utilitarianism emphasize on maximising the good, that is to bring about the greatest amount of good for the greatest number.

questions.Question: As per John Locke, an English philosopher and physician, which is Dot a Natural Right?
questions.solution: Solution:		John Locke was a prominent westen philosopher who conceptualized rights as natural and inalienable. There rights are not dependent on any law of any particular government or culture. They are universal. John Locke believed in natural right to life, liberty, equality and property. Right to vote is a political right.

questions.Question: Who was the second Chief Election Commissioner of India-
questions.solution: Solution:		K.V.K.Sundaram was the second Chief Election Commissioner of India. His term was from 1958 to 1967.

questions.Question: Which was the first state in India to conduct the Election during delimitation-
questions.solution: Solution:		Karnataka held the election in 2008 during the delimitation. Delimitation implies demarcation of elector constituencies based population census.

questions.Question: _______ recommended change in the structure and working of BCCI.
questions.solution: Solution:		Lodha Committee was a three member committee headed by retired Chief Justice of India, R.M. Lodha. It was formed in 2015 which recommended changes in structure and working of BCCI.

questions.Question: Which commission made the recommendations which formed the basis for the Punjab Reorganisation Act which created the states Punjab and Haryana?
questions.solution: Solution:		On the basis of recommendation of Shah commission, State of Haryana was carved out from the state of Punjab by Punjab (Reorganisation)Act,1966.

questions.Question: Indian Parliament can rename or redefine the boundary of a State by-
questions.optionD:
2/3rd majority of the members voting and an
absolute majority of its total membership
questions.solution: Solution:		Parliament of India can rename or redefine the boundary of a state by simply passing the bill with simple majority in both the houses of parliament. And no such bill can be introduced in parliament except on recommendation of President.

questions.Question: Which of the following is under the state?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sovereignty is one of the essential elements of state. A Sovereign state is free from any internal and external undue pressure. State is free to take any decision about its territory and the people.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not a element of the State?
questions.solution: Solution:		State is a physical entity which has four essential elements. These are Sovereignty, Territory or land, Government, Population or Citizens. Any Sovereign state uses Government to bring control over its Territory and Citizens. Army is not an element of state, rather it is an institution which functions under control of Government.

questions.Question: Which of the following is an essential element of the State?
questions.solution: Solution:		State is a physical entity which has four essential elements. These are Sovereignty, Territory or land, Government, Population or Citizens. Any Sovereign state uses Government to bring control over its Territory and Citizens. Army is not an element of state, rather it is an institution which functions under control of Government.

questions.Question: How many legislative assembly seats are in Delhi-
questions.solution: Solution:		Since 1992, Union Territory of Delhi has been provided with a Legislative Assembly and a Council of Ministers headed by a Chief Minister. The strength of assembly has been fixed at 70 members, directly elected by people.

questions.Question: State Highways are maintained by-
questions.optionB: Private companies preferred by state government
questions.solution: Solution:		State Highways in India are laid and maintained by the respective state governments. Whereas National Highways are maintained by National Highways Authority of India (NHAI).

questions.Question: An Ordinary bill passed by the State Assembly can be delayed by the Legislative Counell for maximum period of-
questions.solution: Solution:		State Legislative Council has very limited powers in the passage of bills. Only the ordinary bill can be introduced in legislative council. And any ordinary bill which is introduced in Legislative Assembly will move to Legislative Council after passage, Legislative Councilthen can pass the bill, amend the bill or can delay the bill for maximum period of 4 months.

questions.Question: Which of the following state has 4 legislative council-
questions.solution: Solution:		State Legislative Council is a permanent house and upper house of state legislature, According to Article-168, there are seven states where there is legislative council. These are Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Jammu and Kashmir, Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

questions.Question: The discretionary powers of a Governor is limited in-
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the provisions of Article-163 of Constitution Governor in state have to exercise their executive powers either on advice of Council of Ministers or in their discretion. In the appointment of Chief Minister,dismissal of ministry or government and in dissolution of Legislative Assembly, Governor enjoys full discretion. But while giving assent to the bills he has limited discretion as he cannot withhold assent to the reconsidered bill.

questions.Question: Governor is sworn by-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-153 establishes the office of Governor for each state. Governor of state is appointed by President and sworn by Chief Justice of concerned High Court. In the absence of Chief Justice, the senior most judge of that High Court will administer the oath of Governor.

questions.Question: Which of the following  tatement is not correct about Governor-
questions.optionA:
A person can be appointed as Governor for
two or more states
questions.optionB:
Governor can be tranferred from one state to
another during their tenure
questions.optionC:
President appoints Governor by warrant,
under his hand and seal
questions.optionD:
Minimum age required for a person to become
Governor of a state is 30 years
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-157 provides for qualification for appointment as Governor. According to provision under this article, minimum age required to become Governor of a state is 35 years. After 7th Consitutional Amendment of 1956, a provision was added into Article-153 that a person can be appointed as Governor for two or more states. President appoints Governor and he can also transfer aGovernor from one state to other during his/her tenure.

questions.Question: The Chief Minister is appointed by-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-163 establishes that there shall be a Council of Ministers with Chief Minister as head to aid and advice the Governor in exercise of his functions. And according to Article-164, Chief Minister shall be appointed by Governor of the concerned state.

questions.Question: Which Article of the Indian constitution defines the duties of the Chief Minister?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-167 of Indian constitution defines the duties of the Chief Minister. Under this they are obligated to communicate to Governor of state, all decisions of Council of Ministers related to administrative affairs and proposed legislation of state.

questions.Question: What is maximum determined numbers for the members of the State  Legislative Assemblies-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-170 talks about composition of Legislative Assemblies. And according to it, any Legislative Assembly can have maximum of 500 members. Whereas, minimum strength prescribed for Legislative Assembly is 60. But President through special notification can fix-up strength lower than 60.

questions.Question: Which of the following committee is not a permanent committee of the Parliament-
questions.solution: Solution:		PresentlyStanding committees which are also called permanent committees are 45 in number. These include Departmentally Related Standing Committee, Public Accounts Committee, Estimates Committee, Committee on Public Undertaking, Business Advisory Committee, Committee on Petitions etc.

questions.Question: _____ elects the President and the Vice President and removes judges of Supreme Court and High Court.
questions.optionD: Securities and Exchange Board of India
questions.solution: Solution:		President is elected by collegium consist of MP's of both Houses and MLA's of all states and Union Territories. Vice President is elected by MP's of both Houses of Parliament. Members of Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha needs to pass resolution with two third majority for removal of Judges of Supreme Court and High Court.

questions.Question: Who among the following is not a member of any of the two houses of our country?
questions.solution: Solution:		President is not the member of either house of Parliament. PM, Cabinet Minister, State Minister needs to be member of either house of Parliament to hold any constitutional office in Government of India.

questions.Question: What is the minimum age to become the Prime Minister of India if he or she is a member of Rajya Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		President of India appoints a person as Prime Minister who has completed the age of 30 years in case he or she is a member of Rajya Sabha and 25 years in case of his or her membership in Lok Sabha.

questions.Question: Who among the following issues a notification for prorogation of legislative session?
questions.solution: Solution:		President orders for prorogation of legislative session. Prorogation means continuation of parliament from one session to another. On the contrary adjournment is continuation of session from day to day.

questions.Question: The members of the state legislature exercise control over the council of the ministers through
questions.solution: Solution:		The members of the state legislature exercise control over the council of the ministers through questions and supplementary questions, criticism of its policies and adjournment motion.

questions.Question: The preamble to our constitution includes all the following except
questions.solution: Solution:		The preamble to our constitution includes all the following except adult franchise.

questions.Question: Mainstream Nationalism in India
questions.optionB: aimed at restoration of the Hindu state
questions.optionC: had national socialism as its ultimate goal
questions.optionD: aimed at emancipation from colonial rule
questions.solution: Solution:		Mainstream Nationalism in India aimed at emancipation from colonial rule.

questions.Question: The minimum age required to become the prime minister of India is
questions.solution: Solution:		To be eligible for the position of the Prime Minister of India, a person should: Be a citizen of India. Be a member of either the Lok Sabha or the Rajya Sabha. Complete 25 years of age if he is a member of the Lok Sabha or 30 years if he is a member of the Rajya Sabha.

questions.Question: The objective of the Morley-Minto Reforms was
questions.optionB: to give more powers to local government
questions.optionC: to abolish the post of secretary of the state for India
questions.solution: Solution:		Morley-Minto Reforms of 1909 was primarily aimed at extending Provincial Assemblies. The number of elected members in the Imperial Legislative Council and Provincial Legislative Councils was increased.

questions.Question: The provision to separate the judiciary from the executive  in the public services of the state has been given in :
questions.solution: Solution:		The provision to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the state has been given in Directive Principles of State Policy.

questions.Question: The Constitutional Advisor of the Constituent Assembly was :
questions.solution: Solution:		B. N. Rau was appointed as the Constitutional Adviser to the Constituent Assembly in formulating the Indian Constitution in 1946. He was responsible for the general structure of its democratic framework of the Constitution and prepared its initial draft in February 1948.

questions.Question: Which article of the constitution was called by Dr.  B.R. Ambedkar as the most important article?
questions.solution: Solution:		A mere declaration of fundamental rights in the Constitution is meaningless, useless and worthless without providing an effective machinery for their enforcement, if and when they are violated. Hence, Article 32 confers the right to remedies for the enforcement of the fundamental rights of an aggrieved citizen. In other words, the right to get the Fundamental Rights protected is in itself a fundamental right. This makes the fundamental rights real. That is why Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called Article 32 as the most important article of the Constitution—‘an Article without which this constitution would be a nullity. It is the very soul of the Constitution and the very heart of it’.

questions.Question: The provision of writs as enshrined in the constitution of India is borrowed from:
questions.solution: Solution:		The provision of writs as enshrined in the constitution of India is borrowed from English law.

questions.Question: The writ issued by the court to enquire into the legality of claim of a person to a public office (and thereby preventing illegal usurpation of that office) is known as :
questions.solution: Solution:		The writ issued by the court to enquire into the legality of claim of a person to a public office (and thereby preventing illegal usurpation of that office) is known as Quo Warranto.

questions.Question: The Chairman of Public Accounts Committee in Indian Parliament is-
questions.solution: Solution:		Public Accounts Comrmttee is the oldest Parliamentary Committee. It helps Parliament in strengthening the financial control over executive. It consists of 22 members, out of which 15 are from Lok Sabha and 7 from Rajya Sabha. The chairman of this committee is to be appointed by Speaker of Lok Sabha from among the Lok Sabha members of committee. As a part of healthy parliamentary proceedings, the chairman of this commitee is to be appointed from among the senior opposition members.

questions.Question: Which Parliamentary Committee in India is normally chaired by a prominent member of the opposition?
questions.solution: Solution:		Public Accounts Comrmttee is the oldest Parliamentary Committee. It helps Parliament in strengthening the financial control over executive. It consists of 22 members, out of which 15 are from Lok Sabha and 7 from Rajya Sabha. The chairman of this committee is to be appointed by Speaker of Lok Sabha from among the Lok Sabha members of committee. As a part of healthy parliamentary proceedings, the chairman of this commitee is to be appointed from among the senior opposition members.

questions.Question: The number of parliamentary seats (Lok Sabha) of Punjab is -
questions.solution: Solution:		Punjab has 13 Lok Sabha constituencies. In Rajya Sabha it has representation of 7 seats.

questions.Question: There are total parliamentary seats (Rajya Sabha constituency) in Punjab-
questions.solution: Solution:		Punjab has 7 parliamentary seats for Rajya Sabha. Elections to Rajya Sabha are based on proportional representation by means of single transferable vote. Thetenure of Rajya Sabha MP's are 6 years. However 1/3rd of members retire after every two years.

questions.Question: Which of the following procession has not been adopted from the world's Parliamentary system-
questions.solution: Solution:		Question Hour is a fix time every day from 11:00 to 12:00hrs to allow members of Parliament to ask questions from the members of Council of Ministers. Whereas Motion of thanks is a motion under which the speech of President at the start of first session every year or session after each general election, is discussed and put to vote. This along with Question Hour and oath has been adopted from world's Parliamentary system whereas Zero-Hour is an Indian innovation.

questions.Question: When did India become a Complete Sovereign Democratic Republic-
questions.solution: Solution:		Constitution of India was adopted on 26 November,1949. Preamble along with some others articles was enacted on this day only. Preamble defines India as Sovereign, Democratic, Republic.

questions.Question: The Indian constitution was adopted on-
questions.solution: Solution:		Constitution of India was adopted on 26th November,1949. We can find the mention of date of adoption of constitution in the Preamble of constitution. Preamble along with some provisions of constitution came into force on November26, 1949 itself.

questions.Question: The constitution of India was framed by-
questions.solution: Solution:		Constitution of India was framed by constituent assembly which consisted of total 389 members before partition and 299 members after partition of India.

questions.Question: The Constituent Assembly of India was constituted on the scheme of-
questions.solution: Solution:		Demand for constituent assembly was first accepted in August offer of 1940 by British government But it was constituted on the scheme of Cabinet mission plan 1946.

questions.Question: Which type of democracy do we follow in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Democracy is basically of two types-direct and indirect. In direct democracy people directly participate in policy initiatives. Whereas in indirect democracy or representative democracy policy initiatives are being taken by representatives elected by people. India has representative democracy.

questions.Question: On which principle, the General Indian Election is based on-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-325 of Indian Constitution provides for the general electoral roll for every territorial constituency for election to the Parliament and the State Legislatures. Members elected through General Election represents a constiruency which symbolizes regional representation.

questions.Question: The Article-343 of the Indian Constitution is about-
questions.optionA: Number of seats for the Lok Sabha
questions.optionB: Number of seats for the Rajya Sabha
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-343 of Indian constitution is about official language of Union and according to this article, it shall be Hindi in Devangri Script.

questions.Question: Article-370 of constitution is applicable on which state-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-370 contains temporary and special provisions with respect to the state of Jammu and Kashmir. Jammu and Kashmir has its own Constitution.

questions.Question: Which of the following does not fall under the jurldiction of Election Commission-
questions.optionA: Election of Prime Minister of India
questions.optionD: Allocation of signs to poltical parties
questions.solution: Solution:		As mentioned under Article-324, erection of President is the responsibility of Election Commission. Recognition to political parties and allocation of signs to political parties fall under the jurisdiction of Election Commission under Representation of People Act,1951. Election of Prime Minister does not fall under jurisdiction of election commission rather Prime Minister is nominated by the members of political party having majority in Lok Sabha.

questions.Question: The National Political Party is one which has attained 6% of total vote in-
questions.solution: Solution:		As mentioned under Representation of People Act, 1951 any party can be recognizedas a National Party if it secures six percent of total valid votes polled in four or more States at a General Election to the Lok Sabha or to the Legislative Assembly and in addition, it wins four seats in the Lok Sabha from any State or States, National Parties are entitled to use a symbol for its candidates across the country.

questions.Question: Which form of government believes in giving equal rights and opportunities for women and men?
questions.solution: Solution:		Feminist government believes in ensuring equal rights and opportunities for men and women, both nationally and internationally. Sweden was deemed to have the first feminist government in the world. This doctrine believes in extending economic, social and Political rights to woman as that of men.

questions.Question: In which year was the First Five Year Plan launched in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		First five year plan was presented by first Prime Minister of India, Pt. Jawahar Lal Nehru in year 1951. This plan was mainly focussed on development of primary sector i.e. mainly agriculture.

questions.Question: What is the Example of Direct Democracy in India-
questions.solution: Solution:		Gram Sabha is an example of direct democracy. It is a village assembly consisting of all the registered voters of the village.

questions.Question: Who is the father of Idealism-
questions.solution: Solution:		Greek philosopher,Plato is know as the fathee of Idealism. He depicted an "Ideal state" in his famous book "Republic".

questions.Question: Who advocated the Nazism in Germany-
questions.solution: Solution:		Hitler advocated Nazism in Germany. His autobiography (Mein Kampf) was published during 1924-27. Gottfriend Feder had explained basic concept of Nazism in 1920.

questions.Question:
By which of the following modes can citizenship be acquired in India?
i. By birth, ii. Hereditary, iii. By Registration, iv. By Request
questions.solution: Solution:		A citizen is a person who enjoys full civil and political rights. Citizenship in India can be acquired by 5 ways. These areby Birth, by Registration, by Naturalization,by descent (hereditry), and at the time of incorporation of a new territory into India.

questions.Question: Which State enjoys the distinction of being the first linguistic state of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		A Commission under S.K.Dhar and a Congress Committee under Jawahar Lal Nehru, Sardar Patel and Pattabhi Sitaramayya (JVP Committee) examined the feasibility of re-organisation of states on linguistic basis. Both did not favour a linguistic base. But prolong agitation of people and the death of Potti Sriramalu after 56day hunger strike forced government to create Andhra Pradesh as first linguistic state by separating the Telugu speaking areas from the state of Madras in 1953.

questions.Question: Which of the following categories of citizens of the prescribed age may be registered as a voter?
questions.optionB: Convicted for certain crimes or corruption
questions.solution: Solution:		A non-resident citizen (NRI) is a person holding Indian passport and has stayed for more than 180 days outside India. A NRI has full civil and political rights. Thus, he may be a registered voter.

questions.Question: In which year were the Indian states reorganised on the linguistic basis?
questions.solution: Solution:		After creation of Andhra Pradesh as first linguistic state, there were several other demands for reorganisation of states on linguistic basis. As a result of this, a commission was setup under Justice Fazal Ali with H.N.Kunzru and K.M.Panikkar as members to study the demand. On the basis of this, State Reorganisation Act was passed in 1956. As a result, fourfold distribution of states was replaced by 14 States and six Union Territories via Seventh Constitutional Amendmert.

questions.Question: The States reorganization in 1956 created-

questions.Question: A writ of Mandamus can be issued by the Supreme Court to-
questions.optionA: An official to perform public duty
questions.optionB: The Prime Minister to dissolve the Cabinet
questions.optionD: The Government to pay the salaries to employees
questions.solution: Solution:		Mandamus which literally means 'command' is a writ issued by court to a public official asking him to perform his official duties that he has failed or refused to perform. This writ can be issued only against a government official and not against a private individual or body.

questions.Question: Which of the following writs can be issued only gainst a overnment offlcial?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mandamus which literally means 'command' is a writ issued by court to a public official asking him to perform his official duties that he has failed or refused to perform. This writ can be issued only against a government official and not against a private individual or body.

questions.Question: Who can restrict the fundamental rights of the citizens?
questions.solution: Solution:		Parliament of India can restrict the fundamental rights of citizens. Article-368 provides power to parliament to amend fundamental rights subject to basic structure of constitution.

questions.Question: In which year was the Prevention of terrorism Act (POTA)enacted?
questions.solution: Solution:		Prevention of Terrorism Act (POTA) was enacted in 2002 to deal with crimes like subversion insurgency and terrorism. This act has now been repealed.

questions.Question: Which of the following fundamental right can be  controlled by preventive detention act-
questions.solution: Solution:		Preventive detention infringes the right to freedom of the person who has been detained under preventive detention Act. Article-22 provides for protection against arrest and detention in certain cases, including preventive detention cases.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a Union Territory?
questions.solution: Solution:		First Schedule of constitution specifies the names of States and Union Territories. According to it, currently India has 7 Union Territories including National Capital Territory of Delhi. Others being Andaman and Nicobar, Lakshwadeep, Dadra and Nagar Haveli, Daman and Diu,Chandigarh and Puducherry.

questions.Question: "Foreign jurisdiction" is listed in the ______ list given in the Seventh Schedule in the Constitution of India.
questions.solution: Solution:		Foreign jurisdiction, foreign affairs, defence,communication, are part of Union list. In federal system, there has been clear division and separation of powers to avoid any conflict between centre, state and local government.

questions.Question: "Forests" is listed in the ________ list given in the Seventh Schedule in the Constitution of India.
questions.solution: Solution:		Forests are listed in concurrent list. This list covers 52 items including Criminal Law, IPC, Criminal Procedure, Marriage & divorce, Bankruptcy & Insolvency, Forests , Education.

questions.Question: Which Schedule contains provisions regarding allocation of seats in Rajya Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		Fourth schedule of Indian constitution contains provisions regarding allocation of seats in Rajya Sabha to states and union territories. Allocation of seats is done on the basis of population in states and union territories.

questions.Question: The term 'Fraternity' in the Preamble of the Indian Constitution means a sense of-
questions.solution: Solution:		Fraternity as enshrined in the constitution means a sense of brotherhood prevailing amongst all sections of the people. This is sought to be achieved by making the state secular, guaranteeing fundamental and other rights equally to people of all sections, and protecting their interests.

questions.Question: Under which Article of the Constitution can an individual move to the Supreme Court directly in case of any violation of Fundamental Rights?
questions.solution: Solution:		Remedies for enforcement of fundamental rights conferred by Part-III has been provided under Article-32 of constitution. This article provides the right to citizens to move directly to Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamntal rights and it gives Supreme Court, powers to issu write to enforce fundamental rights of an individual.

questions.Question: Which of the followings is a Political right-
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to contest election is a political right whereas right to freedom, right to life and right to equality before law are fundamental rights.

questions.Question: Right to Education Act came into force on-
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to education act which was passed in 2009 to implement right to education came into force on 1st April,2010.

questions.Question: Right to education in our country is a  _____ right.
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to education is a fundamental right under Article-21(A) of constitution. This article was added into constitution by 86th amendment act of 2002 which provides for free and compulsory education to the children between the ago of 6 to 14 years.

questions.Question: Constitution of India considers free and compulsory education to children up to-
questions.solution: Solution:		Right to education is a fundamental right under Article-21(A) of constitution. This article was added into constitution by 86th amendment act of 2002 which provides for free and compulsory education to the children between the ago of 6 to 14 years.

questions.Question: Which article specifies Imposition of President's Rule in States?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-356 of constitution of India referst of imposition of President's rule or State Emergency. As per provisions of this article, if President feels that State Government is not functioning in accordance to provisions of Constitution, State Government can be dismissed and State Legislative Assembly can be suspended or dissolved.

questions.Question: The President's Rule is imposed on a State in India, when-
questions.optionA: The State Cabinet' of Ministers resigns
questions.optionB: The Governor of the State dies
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-356 of constitution of India referst of imposition of President's rule or State Emergency. As per provisions of this article, if President feels that State Government is not functioning in accordance to provisions of Constitution, State Government can be dismissed and State Legislative Assembly can be suspended or dissolved.

questions.Question: A law can be enacted, or executive order issued, even contrary to Article-19, during proclamation of emergency-
questions.optionA: Casued by war or external aggression
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions of Article-358, during National Emergency imposed due to war or external aggression, rights under Article-19 will be automatically suspended. This means any law can be enacted or executive order issued, even contrary to Article-19 during proclamation of emergency.

questions.Question:
Which among the following Article of the Indian Constitution provides for State emergency and suspends constitutional
arrangement in a State?
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions under Article-356, if President on receipt of report from Governor of State or otherwise is satisfied that a situation has arisen in which Government of state cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution, he may issue a proclamation of State Emergency. By proclamation, President can dismiss State Government. State Legislative Assembly can be suspended dissolved.

questions.Question: Under which of the following articles, president can make the proclamation of emergency in failure of constitutional machinery in any state-
questions.solution: Solution:		As per provisions under Article-356, if President on receipt of report from Governor of State or otherwise is satisfied that a situation has arisen in which Government of state cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution, he may issue a proclamation of State Emergency. By proclamation, President can dismiss State Government. State Legislative Assembly can be suspended dissolved.

questions.Question: The Parliament enjoys legislative power over subjects in
questions.optionD: all the three lists, viz. union list, state list and the concurrent list
questions.solution: Solution:		The Parliament enjoys legislative power over subjects in both union and concurrent list.

questions.Question: The power to prorogue the Lok Sabha rests with
questions.solution: Solution:		Prorogue is the termination of a session of Rajya Sabha or Lok Sabha by an order made by the President. According to article 85(2) the Constitution of India, the President may from time to time prorogue the Houses or either House.

questions.Question: The phrase 'bicameral legislature' means
questions.optionC: a legislature consisting of a lower and an upper chamber
questions.solution: Solution:		A bicameral legislature has legislators in two separate assemblies, chambers, or houses. Bicameralism is distinguished from unicameralism, in which all members deliberate and vote as a single group, and from some legislatures that have three or more separate assemblies, chambers, or houses.

questions.Question: The position of the president which was undermined by the 42nd amendment was subsequently somewhat retrieved by the
questions.solution: Solution:		The position of the president which was undermined by the 42nd amendment was subsequently somewhat retrieved by the 44th amendment act.

questions.Question: The oath of office is administered to the members of state council of ministers by
questions.optionC: chief justice of the state high court
questions.solution: Solution:		The oath of office is administered to the members of state council of ministers by the governor.

questions.Question: Who was the first Speaker of Lok Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		G.V.Mavalankar was elected as first Speaker of Lok Sabha. He served as Speaker of Lok Sabha from 1952 to 1956. Whereas M.A. Ayyangar served as second Speaker of Lok Sabha from 1956 to 1962.

questions.Question: The number of parliamentary seats (Lok Sabha) of Goa is-
questions.solution: Solution:		Goa is the smallest state in India in terms of area. There are two Lok Sabha constituencies in Goa. In Rajya Sabha it has representation of only one seat.

questions.Question: The number of parliamentary seats (Jok Sabha) of Gujarat is-
questions.solution: Solution:		Gujarat is one of the 9 littoral states in India. It has representation of 26 seats in Lok Sabha. In Rajya Sabha it has 11 seats.

questions.Question: Who among the following presides over the Lok Sabha in the absence of Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha?
questions.optionB:
Amember nominated by the members of the
Parliament present in the House
questions.optionC:
A person from the panel formed by: the
Speaker of the Lok Sabha
questions.optionD: A senior most member of the House
questions.solution: Solution:		If the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha, both are absent from a sitting, one of the members or the house out of a panel of six Chairpersons , whom Speaker nominates from time to time, presides.

questions.Question: Who presides the joint sitting of Parliament-
questions.solution: Solution:		In case of a deadlock between the two houses during the passage of certain categories of bills, there is a provision of joint sitting under Article-108 to resolve the deadlock. It can be summoned by the President and it is presided over by the Speaker of Lok Sabha.

questions.Question: In which country political theory of 'Fascism' started?
questions.solution: Solution:		Political theory of Fascism started in Italy under the leadership of Benito Mussolini. Thomas Carlyle was known as the founding father of Fascism.

questions.Question: Who among the following is the ex-officio chairman of the NITI Aayog in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Prime Minister of India is the ex-officio chairman of NITI Aayog. NITI Aayog is government think tank and is formed in 2015 after replacing Planning Commission. NITI Aayog is an acronym of National Institute For Transforming India. It was formed by a resolution passed by Cabinet. It is non-constitutional and non-statutory body.

questions.Question: Who said "Adolf Hitler is Germany and Getmany is Adolf Hitler. He who is committed to Hitler is committed to Germany"-
questions.solution: Solution:		R.Hess said, "Adolf Hitler is Germany and Germany is Adolf Hitler. He who is committed to Hitler is committed to Germany".

questions.Question: Which of the following is necessary for the development of Democratic Institutions-
questions.solution: Solution:		Respect to Individual rights is very necessary for the development of Democratic Institutions, Abraham Lincoln said "democracy is the government of the people,by the people and for the people.

questions.Question: In which of the following American President had visited to China in 1972 to strengthen diplomatic relations-
questions.solution: Solution:		Richard Nixon was the President of America from 1969 to 1974. He visited China in 1972 to strengthen diplomatic relations.

questions.Question: The Chairman of Rajya sabha can be removed from his office only if he is removed from :
questions.solution: Solution:		The Chairman of Rajya sabha can be removed from his office only if he is removed from the office of Vice-President. The Constitution states that the Vice President can be removed by a resolution of the Rajya Sabha passed by an effective majority (i.e.,majority of all the then member of the house) and agreed by the Lok Sabha with simple majority (Article 67(b)).

questions.Question: The parliamentary form of government as prevalent in India emphasizes the interdependence between :
questions.solution: Solution:		The parliamentary form of government as prevalent in India emphasizes the interdependence between the Legislative and Executive Organs.

questions.Question: The constitution of India deals with the organization, composition, duration, officers, procedures, privileges, power of the parliament under:
questions.solution: Solution:		The constitution of India deals with the organization, composition, duration, officers, procedures, privileges, power of the parliament under Article 79 to 122 in Part V. Article 79 of the Indian constitution says that India will have a parliament for making laws to run the democratic set up of the country. Article 79 to 122 in part V of the constitution of India deal with the organization, privileges, and powers and so on of the parliament.

questions.Question: The last session of the existing Lok Sabha after a new Lok Sabha has been elected is called :
questions.solution: Solution:A lame duck session is conducted after election of new members but before they are installed. Hence, in such a session participants vote for the last time as elected officials because of their failure to get re-elected or because they are retiring voluntarily. In the US, it is a term for a person or legislature that continues to hold office after losing an election. The practice in the US of holding presidential elections in November with the winner taking office only in January means that often there are lame duck Presidents.

questions.Question: The main duty of the Speaker Pro-tem of Lok Sabha is :
questions.optionB: To administer oath to the new members.
questions.solution: Solution:Pro-tem speaker is mainly an operating and temporary speaker. To conduct the works in the centre or in state legislatives, pro-tem speaker is appointed for a limited time period. Generally in such a condition when the Lok Sabha and Legislative Assemblies have been elected, but the vote for the speaker and deputy speaker has not taken place, the pro-tem speaker is chosen. Pro-tem speaker is chosen with the agreement of the members of the Lok Sabha and legislative assembly, so that he can carry on the activities till the permanent speaker is not chosen.

questions.Question: How many years after a Finance Commission is constituted by the President-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-280 of the Constitution of India provides for a Finance Commission as a Quasi-Judicial body. It is constituted by the President of India every fifth year or at such earlier time as he consider necessary.

questions.Question: Who constitutes the Finance Commission-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-280 of the Constitution of India provides for a Finance Commission as a Quasi-Judicial body. It is constituted by the President of India every fifth year or at such earlier time as he consider necessary.

questions.Question: Under which of the following Article of Indian constitution, the verdict of Central Administrative Tribunal can be challenged in Supreme Court-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-323(A) of the Constitution provides for the establishment of administrative tribunals which can be created by an act of Parliament for the adjudication of disputes relating to the recruitment and conditions ofservice of government servants. Any verdict of this tribunal can be challenged in Supreme Court.

questions.Question: Under which of the following article the Election Commission was established-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-324 established the office of Election Commission in India. According to this article, power of superintendence, direction and control of elections of Parliament, State Legislatures, the office of President and that of Vice-President of India shall be vested in the Election Commission. Election Commission consists of one Chief Election Commissioner and such other number of Election Commissioners as decided by the President from time to time.

questions.Question: Who was the first Chief Election Commissioner of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-324 of constitution establishes office of Election Commission Which consists of one Chief Election Commissioner and two Election Commissioners. Sukumar Sen was first Chief Election Commissioner of India who served from 1950 to 1958.

questions.Question: Who decides the salary and allowances of the Speaker of the Lok Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-97 of the Indian Constitution authorizes, the Parliament to fix the salary and allowances payable to the Speaker of Lok Sabha and also to Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha. Second Schedule of Constitution contains the provisions relating to salaries and allowances of certain office bearers including Speaker and Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha.

questions.Question: Which bill cannot originate in Rajya Sabha ?
questions.solution: Solution:		As mentioned under Article-109(1), a money bill can not be introduced in Rajya Sabha. It can only be introduced Lok Sabha with prior recommendation of President.

questions.Question: Who is the custodian of Consolidated Fund of India-
questions.solution: Solution:		As mentioned under Article-266(1), all revenues received by Government of India, all loans raised by that Government by issue of treasury bills and all money received by Government in repayment of loans, together form Consolidated Fund of India. No money can be deposited or withdrawn from this fund without prior approval of Parliament. That is why Parliament which is Union legislature in India, is called custodian of Consolidated Fund of India.

questions.Question: Lok Sabha is the House of the________ Parliament of India-
questions.solution: Solution:		As mentioned under Article-79 Parliement consists of President and two houses that are known as Council of States (Rajya Sabha) and House of People (Lok Sabha). Lok Sabha is called as Lower house of Parliament whereas Rajya Sabha is the Upper house of Parliment.

questions.Question: What is the name of Upper house of Indian Parliament?
questions.solution: Solution:		As mentioned under Article-79 Parliement consists of President and two houses that are known as Council of States (Rajya Sabha) and House of People (Lok Sabha). Lok Sabha is called as Lower house of Parliament whereas Rajya Sabha is the Upper house of Parliment.

questions.Question: What Constitutional provision enables the Central Government to provide reservations in jobs and educational institutions for the weaker sections of the society?
questions.solution: Solution:		Though Article-16 prohibits discrimination in public employment on the basis of religion race caste sex place of birth descent and residence or any of them, It allows state to make provisions for reservation for weaker sections of society, if in opinion of state they are not adequately represented.

questions.Question: Which one of the followingis an item included in the list of Fundamental Duties of an Indian citizen in the Constitution?
questions.optionB:
To develop scientific temper humanism and
the spirit of enquiry and reform
questions.optionC:
To pay all taxes to government regularly and
correctly
questions.optionD:
Not to assault any public servant during
performance of his duties
questions.solution: Solution:		To develop scientific temper, humanism and spirit of enquiry is a fundamental duty under constitution along with duty to promote brotherhood and establish dignity of womento preserve rich cultural heritage to protect environment, to safe guard public property and to strive for excellence.

questions.Question: Which of the following does not come under Fundamental Duty?
questions.optionB: To protect and improve the natural environment
questions.optionD: To protect freedom of speech and Expression
questions.solution: Solution:		To protect freedom od speech and expression is encompassed in the list of Fundamental Rights. Fundamental Duties are 11 in number and has been incorporated in the constitution on recommendation of Sardar Swam Singh Committee through 42nd Amendment of Constitution.

questions.Question: Fill in the blank-"Rights ___ duties"-
questions.solution: Solution:		We have to follow our duties within the limits of our Constitutional and Legal rights so it can be said that rights direct duties.

questions.Question: How many writs can be issued by supreme court?
questions.solution: Solution:		Writ is an order issued by Supreme Court or High Courts to enforce rights. It is a concept originated under Roman law but developed under British. Both Supreme Court and High Court can issue 5 types of writs. These are Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari and Quo Warranto.

questions.Question: The write which literally means ‘by what authority or warrant’ and is issued by the court to enquire the legality of a claim of a person to public office is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The write which literally means ‘by what authority or warrant’ and is issued by the court to enquire the legality of a claim of a person to public office is called Quo Warranto.

questions.Question: The concept of martial law has been borrowed in India from
questions.solution: Solution:		The concept of martial law has been borrowed in India from the English common law. However, the expression 'martial law' has not been defined anywhere in the Constitution. Literally, it means 'military rule'.

questions.Question: Prohibitation of traffic in human being and forced labour is laid down in:
questions.solution: Solution:		Traffic in human beings and beggar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law is laid down in Article 23.

questions.Question: The Directive Principles of State Policy are enshrined in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Directive Principles of State Policy are enshrined in Part IV of the Constitution(Article 36-51).

questions.Question: By which act a nation wince network to provide free and competent legal  aid to the poor and to organize lok adalats for promoting equal justice has been established
questions.optionB: The Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955
questions.solution: Solution:		The National Legal Services Authority (NALSA) has been constituted under the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987 to provide free Legal Services to the weaker sections of the society and to organize Lok Adalats for amicable settlement of disputes.

questions.Question: President of India can be removed from his office by-
questions.solution: Solution:		Constitution of India under Article-61 has conferred power to Parliament to impeach President of India for violation of constitution, Any resolution seeking impeachment of President must be passed by both the houses of Parliament with special majority of not less than two-third of total membership of the house. So far,no President has been impeached.

questions.Question: Who held the post of President twice?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr. Rajendra Prasad, the first President of India held the office of President from 1950 to 1962. In 1957 he was re-elected to the office of President, becoming the only President to hold the post twice. S.Radhakrishnan was second President of India whereas K.R. Narayanan was the first candidate to get elected as President from marginalised section of society.

questions.Question: Who completed two successive regimes of the Vice-President of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dr.Radhakrishnan served for two successive tenures as Vice President of India from 1952-57 and 1957-62. He became the second President of India in 1962 and served till 1967. After him, Mohd. Hamid Ansari has also served two successive tenures as Vice President. He served from 2007 to 2017.

questions.Question: Narendra Modi is the Prime Minister of India-
questions.solution: Solution:		Former Chief Minister of Gujarat, Narendra Modi is 14th Prime Minister of Independent India. He is leadingthe Government formed by 16th Lok Sabha.

questions.Question: In single transferable voting system, each member can Express its verdict by-
questions.optionC: One less than the filled members
questions.solution: Solution:		In single transferable voting system, each voter can Express its verdict by voting for all the candidates. He or she has to write preferences among the candidates while voting. Approximately in all indirect elections in India like election of President, Vice President, Rajya Sabha etc., this system is followed.

questions.Question: Which of the following judgements stated that 'Secularism' and 'Federalism are the basic features of the Indian Constitution?
questions.solution: Solution:		The concept of basic structure was given by supreme Court in Keshwananda Bharti case, 1973. At that time court did not define what is basic structure. Supreme court in subsequent cases defined some of the basic structures. In S.R. Bommai case, 1994 which was related , to misuse of article 356 i.e, state emergency or President's rule, Supreme Court stated 'Secularism' and 'Federalism' as basic structures of constitution.

questions.Question: The Constituent Assembly which enacted the Constitution of Indian, its members were-
questions.optionB:
Elected by the Legislative Assemblies of
different provinces
questions.solution: Solution:		The members of constituent assembly were elected indirectly by the members of Provincial Assemblies in the ratio of one member per one million population by method of proportional representation through single transferable vote system.

questions.Question: The original constitution of India was published in?
questions.solution: Solution:		The original constitution of India took nearly 5 years to publish and it was published in Dehradun.

questions.Question: The original 1950 Constitution of India is preserved in-
questions.solution: Solution:		The original constitution of India was not typeset or printed but written in beautiful calligraphy by Prem Behari Narain Raizada. The document is now preserved in a secial helium-filled case in library of Parliament.

questions.Question: Which of the following act suggested the post of Comptroller and Auditor General?
questions.solution: Solution:		The system of government accounting and auditing through post of Comptroller and Auditor General as it exists today is legacy of British Raj. The introduction of constitutional reforms in 1919 through GOI Act, 1919 brought about statutory recognition to the post of Comptroller and Auditor General.

questions.Question: The directive principle of state policy has been adopted from which constitution?
questions.solution: Solution:		Part-IV of Indian constitution, Article 36 to 51 describes DPSP which has been adopted from Irish constitution. Other Provisions borrowed from Irish constitution are Method of election of president and nomination of members in Rajya Sabha by President.

questions.Question: Which of the following was a popular slogan of French revolution?
questions.solution: Solution:		Popular slogan of French Revolution (1789) was "Liberty, Equality and Fraternity". These three are also ideals of constitution of India along with 'Justice' which is inspired from Rusian revolution.

questions.Question: The method of amending the constitution by popular veto is found in-
questions.solution: Solution:		Popular veto is a form of direct democracy, where voters also participate in legislation through a petition. This system is found in Switzerland.

questions.Question: The system of nomination of members of Rajya Sabha has been borrowed from the constitution-
questions.solution: Solution:		President of India nominates 12 members to Rajya Sabha. Any person having special knowledge and practical Experience in art, science, literature and social service can be nominated to Rajya Sabha. We borrowed this feature from Ireland.

questions.Question: The Presidential Government operates on the principles of-
questions.optionA: Division of powers between centre and states
questions.solution: Solution:		Presidential form of government is that form of government in which there is separation of powers between executive and legislature. Here executive is not the part of legislature unlike parliamentary form of govt.

questions.Question: The members of the panchayat are
questions.optionB: the electorates of the respective territorial constituencies
questions.optionC: nominated by local self-government minister of the state
questions.optionD: nominated by the block development organization
questions.solution: Solution:		 The Members of Gram Panchayats, Panch of Gram Kutchahry, Members of Panchayat Samiti and Zila Parishad are elected directly by the electorates of the respective territorial constituencies through universal adult franchise.

questions.Question: The power to decide an election petition is vested in the
questions.solution: Solution:		Parliament has enacted Section 80-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 providing that the “High Court” shall be the authority for presentment of election petitions under Article 329(b) of the Constitution.

questions.Question: The Parliament of India can make use of the residuary powers
questions.optionC: during national emergency as well as constitutional emergency as well in a state
questions.solution: Solution:		The Parliament of India can make use of the residuary powers at all times.

questions.Question: The members of Lok Sabha hold office for a term of
questions.solution: Solution:		Members of the Lok Sabha are elected by adult universal suffrage and a first-past-the-post system to represent their respective constituencies, and they hold their seats for five years or until the body is dissolved by the President on the advice of the council of ministers.

questions.Question: The Parliament exercises control over council of ministers, the real executive, in several ways. Which one of the following has been wrongly listed as a method of control over executive?
questions.solution: Solution:		none of the above

questions.Question: Which of the following item is in "concurrent list"-
questions.solution: Solution:		Labour union is a subject of Concurrent list. Whereas, inter-state rivers and citizenship are under Union list. Local governance is a subject under State list.

questions.Question: Liberalism is a symbol of-
questions.optionC: Freedom of Social,Political and Economic aspects
questions.solution: Solution:		Liberalismis a political ideology which includes a broad spectrum of political philosophies that consider individual liberty to be the most important political goal, and emphasize individual rights and equality of opportunity. It includes Social, Religions Political and economical freedom.

questions.Question: _______ makes laws on matters included in Union List and Concurrent List.
questions.optionD: Securities and Exchange Board of India
questions.solution: Solution:		Lok Sabha makes law on matters enumerated inUnion and Concurrent list. However, matters not mentioned in any of list is to be tackled by Union. Federation delineates separation of powers and subjects ensure smooth functioning of government at all levels.

questions.Question: Which of the following term is not used in the preamble of the constitution-
questions.solution: Solution:		Nowhere in the constitution, the world "Federal" being mentioned, Whereas Preamble of India declare India to be a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic and Republic polity.

questions.Question: Where is the objective of "Social justice" articulated in constitution?
questions.solution: Solution:		Objective of social along with political and economic justice has been articulated in Preamble of constitution.

questions.Question: What is the maximum age limit for the President post of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		There is a provision of minimum age which is 35 years to become President of India. But there is no such Provision of maximum age limit for the post of President.

questions.Question: What is the minimum age for the post of Prime Minister of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		To become the Prime Minister of India, a person should be a member of either house of Parliament. In case of his membership in Rajya Sabha, minimum age required is 30 years whereas in case of membership in Lok Sabha, it is 25 years.

questions.Question: Under which pardoning power of the President, duration of sentence is reduced without changing its character?
questions.solution: Solution:		Under Article-72 of the constitution, The President of India is authorised to grant pardon, reprieve, respite or remission of punishment. Remission is reduction in prisoner's sentence without changing the character or nature of punishment. Commutation - Changing the character of punishment. Reprieve - Its a temporary relief or postponment of punishment, specially in death sentence. Respite - Awarding lesser sentence than prescribed because of special circumstances eg. Pregnancy of women offender.

questions.Question: Under which pardoning power of the President, one form of punishment is substituted by a lighter from?
questions.solution: Solution:		Under Article-72, President is empowered to substitute one form of punishment with lighter one. It is called commutation of sentence.

questions.Question: According to the Indian Constitution, the vacancy in the office of the President of India shall be filled within-
questions.solution: Solution:		Under normal circumstances, election process to fill the vacancy caused by expiration of the term of office ofPresident which is of 5 years, shall be completed before Expiration of that term. But an election to fill the vacancy in office of President occuring due to his death, resignation or impeachment or otherwise, shall be held within 6 months from the date of occurance of such vacancy.

questions.Question: A motion moved by Member of Parliament when he feels a minister has committed a breach of privilege of the House is called-
questions.solution: Solution:		Privilege motion is concerned with the breach of Parliamentary privileges by a Minister. It is moved by a member when he feels that a Minister has committed a breach of privilege of house or of one or more of its members by withholding facts of a case or by giving wrong or distorted facts.

questions.Question: Which Article gives the power to the Parliament to make law on subjects of state list-
questions.solution: Solution:		Provisions under Article-249 empowers Parliament to make laws on the subjects of state list. According to the provisions under this article, if Rajya Sabha in supreme national interest, initiates a proposal supported by not less than two-third of members present and voting, thenParliament can make laws on the subjects of state list. A resolution passed by Rajya Sabha under Article-249 can remain in force for maximum time period of 1 year.

questions.Question: If Parliament has to legislate with respect to a matter in the state list, the proposal for such is to be approved by-
questions.optionA:
Lok Sabha, Rajya Sabha and Legislature of
related State
questions.optionB: Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha both
questions.solution: Solution:		Provisions under Article-249 empowers Parliament to make laws on the subjects of state list. According to the provisions under this article, if Rajya Sabha in supreme national interest, initiates a proposal supported by not less than two-third of members present and voting, thenParliament can make laws on the subjects of state list. A resolution passed by Rajya Sabha under Article-249 can remain in force for maximum time period of 1 year.

questions.Question: How many seats are reserved for representatives of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in Lok Sabha?
questions.solution: Solution:		Provisions under Article-330 provides for reservation of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in House of People i.e Lok Sabha. At present, in Lok Sabha seats reserved for Scheduled Castes is 84 while for Scheduled Tribes it is 47. There is no provision of reservation for Schedule Castes and Scheduled Tribe in Rajya Sabha.

questions.Question: The Chairman of Public Accounts Committee of Parliament is appointed by-
questions.solution: Solution:		Public Accounts Comrmttee is the oldest Parliamentary Committee. It helps Parliament in strengthening the financial control over executive. It consists of 22 members, out of which 15 are from Lok Sabha and 7 from Rajya Sabha. The chairman of this committee is to be appointed by Speaker of Lok Sabha from among the Lok Sabha members of committee. As a part of healthy parliamentary proceedings, the chairman of this commitee is to be appointed from among the senior opposition members.

questions.Question: Who is empowered to transfer a Judge from one High Court to another High Court ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-222 deals with Part-VI of constitution which is related to subject matters of state government or machinery. As per provisions of Article-222, President may; after consultation with Chief Justice of India, transfer a judge from one High Court to any other High Court.

questions.Question: A proceeding under Article-226 in case of detention of a person is a-
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-226 of Indian constitution gives the authority to High Courts to issue writs in case of violation of Fundamental Rights and other legal rights. In case of illegal detention of a person, court issues Habeas corpus writ whicsh is part of criminal proceeding.

questions.Question: Article-228 of the Indian Constitution "Transfer of certain cases to High Court" deals with?
questions.optionA: The Directive Principles of State Policy
questions.optionD: The fundamental rights of the Indian Citizen
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-228 of Indian constitution, which is related to the chapter of High Courts in states under Part-VI of constitution, deals with subject matters of State Government or machinery. This article contains provisions with respect to transfer of certain cases to High Court.

questions.Question: Article-231 of the Indian Constitution "Establishment of a common High Court for two or more States" deals with?
questions.optionB: The Directive Principles of State Policy
questions.optionD: The fundamental rghts of the Indian Citizen
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-231 of the Indian constitution which is related to the chapter of High Courts in states under Part-VI of constitution, deals with subject matters of State Government or machinery. As per provisions under this article parliament may by law establish a common High Court for two or more states. For example - Punjab and Haryana has common High Court.

questions.Question: The pension of the judge of High Court is charged on-
questions.solution: Solution:		Articlel-112(3) mentions the expenditure that shall be charged on Consolidated Fund of India. Charged expenditure under this article includes salary and allowances of President, Chairman and deputy Chairman, of Rajya Sabha, Speaker and deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha, salaries and pensions of judges of Supreme Court, pensions of Judges of High Court and salary and pension of CAG, Whereas salary of Judges of High Court is charged upon Consolidated Fund of State.

questions.Question: Uniform Civil Code is mentioned in which article of Indian Constitution?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-44 under Directive Principles of State Policy deals with uniform civil court for citizens. Uniform civil court is an idea of having same personal law irrespective of religion.

questions.Question: Under the Directive Principles of State Policy up to what age of the children they are expected to be provided free and compulsory education?
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-45 under Directive Principles of State Policy provides for directive of early chilhood care and education to children below the age of six years. Based on this directive Union Government has passed Right to Education Act 2010 which provides for free and compulsory education to children between the age of 6 to 14 years. Article-21(A) under Part-III also provides for fundamental right to education till the age of 14 years.

questions.Question: Where is the Constitutional power located enabling the Central Government to legislate on cow slaughter?
questions.optionA:
Entry 17, List III in Schedule VII Prevention
of Cruelty to Animals
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-48 under Directive Principles of State Policy enables the Central Government and State Governments to legislate on cow slaughter. According to this article state shall endeavour to organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern scientific lines and shall take steps to improve breed and prohibition of slaughter of cows and calves and other milch and draught cattle.

questions.Question: Article-48(A) of the Indian Constitution "Protection and improvement of environment and safeguarding of forests and wild life" deals with?
questions.optionC: The fundamental rights of the Indian Citizen
questions.optionD: the directive principles of state poli
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-48(A) of Indian constitution deals with Directive Principles of State Policy under Part-IV of constitution. This article was added into constitution by 42nd Amendment Act 1976 to include a directive for protection and improvement of environment and safeguarding of forests and wildlife.

questions.Question: Separation of the judiciary from the executive has been provided in one of the following parts of the Indian Constitution-
questions.optionC: The Directive Principles of State Policy
questions.solution: Solution:		Article-50 under Directive Principles of State Policy provides for the directive of separation of judiciary from executive. According to this article State shall take steps to seperate judiciary from executive in public services of state.
